PG1-483 (and 484) show it working.  Note that the throttle test case for concurrent checking now performs exactly N+1 invokes and is thus "tight".
In general: Has it been verified that this override approach is necessary and cannot completely be done in ansible? @lehoanganh @domdom82 ?
green PG 485
Yes, I have talked to both of them about this.
retesting one last time at PG1-490 - passed

Tests for view and for the annotations is written.
New PG2#197 is running.
The CLI updates look good. I tested them as well.
Last travis build got stuck building swift image due to network issues. Re-trying.

@rabbah It is actually difficult to sink the counter without contorted logic because the original code is written as if `/init` is part of container creation but really `/init` is user code and subject to those failure modes and I think the code must be refactored so control flow and various case classes reflect this.  Without a rewrite it will be too easy to double-count or undercount with exceptional paths.
Duplicate of https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/387?
Yes, I guess it's a duplicate.   Closing ... will track in #387

Addendum:   we earlier decided to additionally move the 'whisk' object to an imported npm module, so we can run whisk actions in normal node.js runtimes rather than relying on the nodejsaction base docker image to provide the whisk object.
LGTM
Anything else on this one?
The cloudant view is removed and PG2#205 is running.
PG1#498 is running

In a quick chat with @domdom82 and @lehoanganh they stated that this would be possible by removing the global "default" and use a specific limit for each deployment. Would it make sense to do that instead?

We considered this. Since the limits are overridden to a lower value in only a very small number of deployments (1 currently), it makes more sense to do it this way rather than modify `N` environment files which all will have the same value.

@perryibm this reminds me - we should lower the limit for the `mac` environment also (until we merge that with `local`).
this looks good. on top of this, for #1260, we will need to excise the cacheKeys bits, confirm?
yes - we don't need to cache both w/ and w/o rev. deferring those bits to your pr unless directed otherwise.
Per @jasonpet this is temporary and will be corrected from the push-notification test suite. Should we hold off?
great, i'll merge this into my branch and clean up the cacheKeys cruft
Anything else on this one?
no pg needed.

```
> wsk list 
error: Unable to obtain namespace entities for namespace 'default': The connection failed, or timed out. (HTTP status code 502)
> wsk action list
error: Unable to list action(s): The connection failed, or timed out. (HTTP status code 502)
> wsk trigger list
error: Unable to obtain the trigger list for namespace '_': The connection failed, or timed out. (HTTP status code 502)
> wsk rule list
error: Unable to obtain list of rules: The connection failed, or timed out. (HTTP status code 502)
> wsk activation list
error: Unable to obtain list of activations: The connection failed, or timed out. (HTTP status code 502)
> wsk package list 
error: Unable to obtain package list: The connection failed, or timed out. (HTTP status code 502)
```

almost - the error messages should be more consistent and there's one more instance of `_`.
I moved the test and rewrote the limit check. Merged as https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/commit/a9ebadfa454434e4998a39dfb7a5b82159cac1f1.

These are unused references. The error messages are defined in a singleton object shared by the controller and the tests.

Here are other Python scripts that rely on the files from the Python CLI: tools/health/killComponent, tools/health/kvstore, tools/deploy/deployInvoker. These files might need to be updated to accommodate your purposed changes.
I would not recommend having a two copies of wskprop.py, and wskutil.py in different locations as they might accidentally diverge over time.

> I would not recommend having a two copies of wskprop.py, and wskutil.py in different locations as they might accidentally diverge over time.

They are already different - I removed the code that is not needed by wskadmin. We could rename one set of these files but since the code in `corePython/cli` is transitioning, I view this as unnecessary. More cleanup will happen in `corePython/cli` to remove dependence on `wskprops.py` later.
Please install https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/tools/eclipse/scala.properties into your Eclipse or adjust your settings accordingly. Mostly 2 spaces vs. 4 spaces.

forgot to add, the reason behind this it's a user feature that the CLI could have the ability to self check if it's outdated and even download a new version.

Also helpful for a download web page UI if they provide the links to the download the binary they can show the "version" and the "date" that was updated.
@dubeejw about cli version, this can be handle as a new issue/enhancement doesn't have to be part of this PR to define "cli":"platforms":{..}
pg1/518 approved.
@paulcastro please add any doc changes required based on this new content.

Please add a logging statement showing the global limit to ease debugging.  Localizing is good.  However, we are summing over the user map for every activation so if there are a lot of users this might become a bottleneck.  Probably not worth worrying about as even 10K users would still cause it to take maybe 100K cycles (since L2 cache hit is about 10/cycle) which would be about 0.05ms.  Of course, as we scale up anything that is O(users) on every invocation will be unsustainable.
Reminder:  update go cli (python gone)
Documentation updated.
Thanks - consul work still in queue but getting bumped.   For this temp fix, has it been tested with an actual restart?   Regular PG won't test this I think.
If we want to provide the ability to create parameters and annotations via `wsk action create actionName artifactName -pf params.json -af annots.json` we will need to update the database schema.

we have amended the state diagram shown in the picture so that, rather than failing fast on read-under-write, we read-around the cache. this allows us to preserve sequential consistency, meanwhile avoiding pollution of the cache with zombie entries
I guess the testing lesson is that since we do not delete the blackbox image, the pulling aspect can regress without us knowing.

We do have a test for a good black box action - Adding a new test for a bogus one (random string hopefully good enough).

Since a docker run also does a pull, there was no functional regression (just a performance one).
I've made the cosmetic changes.
I mean to test that "pull" is always working we would need to pre-delete the image otherwise the cache could delay revelation of the bug for a very long time.

@perryibm check the added test for a bad pull.
when running in travis, the registry is wiped, no?
as a transition step, the CLI could remap the JSON to the required schema. These two features can be added separately.

Well yeah, i tried locally and it counted from the state where it left of.

I will verify and merge this.

The change to the `couchdb` deploy task causes this failure on a mac with docker-machine:

reliably reproduced with

```
ansible-playbook -i environments/mac teardown.yml
ansible-playbook -i environments/mac couchdb.yml
ansible-playbook -i environments/mac openwhisk.yml
ansible-playbook -i environments/mac couchdb.yml -e mode=clean
ansible-playbook -i environments/mac couchdb.yml
```

fatal: [192.168.99.100]: FAILED! => {"changed": true, "cmd": "df -h", "delta": "0:00:00.003609", "end": "2016-09-22 00:00:57.963466", "failed": true, "rc": 1, "start": "2016-09-22 00:00:57.959857", "stderr": "df: /mnt/sda1/var/lib/docker/aufs/mnt/2f35659bdca922697e809d67d1007421d17bf0b938081217739271ae57c0fd60: Permission denied\ndf: /mnt/sda1/var/lib/docker/containers/5a46ae627b8d586c2a86955d3cb1cf3aa97155fa024fae26954b89e5298c5d6b/shm: Permission denied\ndf: /var/run/docker/netns/50a4a5d6d53e: Permission denied" ...

@rabbah , hmm, strange. haven't seen that permissions error yet, perhaps docker-machine doesn't allow the user to run that df command. my last push added a conditional to only run that df -h command when a volume has been created/mounted by the provision playbook, so you shouldn't be seeing that any more. can you confirm?
Apologies for one last round of nits. No PG needed after changes, travis is sufficient.
pg2/223 approved.

I think this is ready for review. 

`596 tests completed, 1 failed, 19 skipped` - swift action timed-out, unrelated to these changes. 

Once I address your comments, I'll squash the second commit.
Superseeded by #1305.

@perryibm very valid concern. I expect we can soften this once the loadbalancer itself keeps track of the requests so we'ld have a local "overallCount" aswell? Can refactor then?

Added the log.

thanks for the writeup @sjfink . 

a few thoughts / comments on this:
- naming: instead of gateway', what about calling it '(api-)mapping'? the rationale is...we're not allow crud operations of gateways or descriptors of gateways, but rather of these mappings?
- have we thought through what the master record of these mappings is going to be? eg if we allow creating them via the ow api -- where would we be storing them? e.g. if we store them in the ow db and in the gw itself, we might run into integrity problem given users can also interact with the gw without going through the ow api.
- cardinality / lifecycle dependency: what constitutes the boundaries of a mapping? eg if i execute `wsk action restify <actionname>`, i assume that is going to result in the creation of mapping for that action, right? how would i add more routes to a mapping (eg would i have to specify the mapping name (to your earlier point) as part of `wsk action restify`? can a mapping refer to multiple actions (i think the answer should probably be 'yes', given a mapping is imho an expression of an api) ?
pg2/228 approved (more pending).
@domdom82 it's safe to upgrade to 1.12 for dev environment?

Another mismatch:
Travis CI is configured with overlay `--storage-driver=overlay` [tools/travis/setup.sh#L4](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/tools/travis/setup.sh#L4)

```
sudo -E bash -c 'echo '\''DOCKER_OPTS="-H tcp://0.0.0.0:4243 -H unix:///var/run/docker.sock --storage-driver=overlay"'\'' > /etc/default/docker'
```

Ubuntu and Vagrant is configured with aufs `--storage-driver=aufs` [tools/ubuntu-setup/docker.sh#L20](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/tools/ubuntu-setup/docker.sh#L20)

```
sudo -E bash -c 'echo '\''DOCKER_OPTS="-H tcp://0.0.0.0:4243 -H unix:///var/run/docker.sock --api-enable-cors --storage-driver=aufs"'\'' >> /etc/default/docker'

```

should make them match? safe to update ubuntu script to use overlay?

there is two sides to this: in theory, you could update those three files in one step.
I did not do it yet because I wanted to walk up the pipeline first and update all servers before updating any clients. 

if you had provisioned a vagrant or docker machine and wanted to talk to any system of our pipeline, it would fail you would not be able to talk to those systems (e.g. registry).

it is safer to have a 1.9 client talk to a 1.12 server than have a 1.12 client talk to a 1.9 server.

but I do get the point of the mismatch on travis. we just started with travis because it is the start of our pipeline.

regarding the aufs vs. overlay yes that is a mismatch and it should all be overlay. also cors is no longer used. (never was actually)
also pg2/230 and 231.
LGTM - please rebase and final PG since there have been a lot of changes in the general area
227 was not clean - retrying PG2 232

This is a comment to track naming suggestions for the entity in our REST API which is a "collection of routes".  Please edit this comment to add more suggestions.

Options include:
-  gateway
-  mapping
-  route-collection
-  route-set
-  api-mapping
-  api-map
  ....

> if we store them in the ow db and in the gw itself, we might run into integrity problems

Yes, there should be a single database which is the source of truth, and a single service which maintains the source of truth.   For now, the OW database will be the source of truth since there is no other option.

> cardinality

Let's restrict this issue to the API, not the CLI or UX.   I hope the API design above is clear that a "route collection ('gateway' entity)" contains a set of routes.
PG1 526 was fine.
rebase/merged
You must be right that in travis, it's clean.  But wouldn't that mean that for a while we are not pulling at all?  Then how could tests pass?
Created an issue for the additions to content.json: https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/1309.
docker run pulls if needed.
@csantanapr, I opened an issue for your suggestions. Anything else on this one?

Not sure that parsing the user provided JSON the way we need it for the key/value fields will be possible in Go since it is a strongly-typed language. We are thinking about having the user input that is specified in a file be what is sent directly to the REST interface. For example, a file could contain this JSON `{"paramKey": "paramValue"}`, which would be forwarded to the backend for create invocations. With our current functionality that would be the equivalent of passing `-p paramKey paramValue`, which would be converted to `{"key": "paramKey", "value": "paramValue"}` before sent to the backend.
